metadata.titleEn: Qilian Mountains integrated observatory network: Dataset of Heihe integrated observatory network (phenology camera observation data set of mixed forest superstation, 2018)
metadata.description:
The dataset contains phenological camera observation data collected at the Arou Superstation in the midstream of the Heihe integrated observatory network from June 13 to November 16, 2018. The instrument was developed with data processed by Beijing Normal University. The phenomenon camera integrates data acquisition and data transmission functions. The camera captures high-quality data with a resolution of 1280×720 by looking-downward. The calculation of the greenness index and phenology are following 3 steps: (1) calculate the relative greenness index (GCC, Green Chromatic Coordinate, calculated by GCC=G/(R+G+B)) according to the region of interest, (2) perform gap-filling for the invalid values, filtering and smoothing, and (3) determine the key phenological parameters according to the growth curve fitting (such as the growth season start date, Peak, growth season end, etc.) There are also 3 steps for coverage data processing: (1) select images with less intense illumination, (2) divide the image into vegetation and soil, and (3) calculate the proportion of vegetation pixels in each image in the calculation area. After the time series data is extracted, the original coverage data is smoothed and filtered according to the time window specified by the user, and the filtered result is the final time series coverage. This data set includes relative greenness index (Gcc).
Please refer to Liu et al. (2018) for sites information in the Citation section.

background: Arid and semiarid regions represent approximately 30 % of the global terrestrial surface area (Dregne, 1991; Scanlon et al., 2006), and dryland expansion occurs under climate change, especially in developing countries (Huang et al., 2016). An oasis is a unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas that is not only the core of regions’ ecological environment but also the foundation of their economic development, especially in western China, which has been an important part of the “Silk Road” since ancient times. Oases comprising less than 10 % of the total area of arid regions support more than 90 % of the population in these regions of China (Chu et al., 2005; Li et al., 2016; Zhou et al., 2022). The oasis–desert system plays a crucial role in maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity (Zhang and Zhao, 2015). Extensive studies have investigated energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas based on field and remote-sensing observations (Taha et al., 1991; Potchter et al., 2008; Xue et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2019; Zhou et al., 2022) and numerical simulations (Chu et al., 2005; Meng et al., 2009; Georgescu et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2020). In addition, oasis–desert areas located in semiarid regions have been found to be carbon sinks by previous researchers (Tagesson et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2019); thus, they can significantly affect the carbon balance of arid regions and play an increasingly important role within the global carbon cycle.
research objective: Therefore, it is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in order to achieve the goal of sustainable oasis development. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis. A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases; moreover, long-term observations are indispensable.
challenges: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, especially in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin (Zhao et al., 2013), the Aral Sea basin (Stanev et al., 2004; Crétaux et al., 2009), and the Lake Urmia basin (Stone, 2015).
methods: In this study, we present a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems that consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021. Half-hourly turbulent flux data were acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The hydrometeorological data (including radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles; gradients of air temperature and humidity and of wind speed and direction; and air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles) were observed from automatic weather stations with a 10 min average period as well as the groundwater table data. Moreover, vegetation and soil parameters were also supplemented in the datasets. The data processing and quality control procedure can be divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing.
dataset: The study area comprises the middle and lower reaches of the HRB, located in the arid regions of western China, that receive water from the typical cryosphere of the upper reaches. A total of 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations have been established in these regions since 2012 – 2 superstations and 9 ordinary stations. The dataset of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas reported in this study (including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes; hydrometeorological data; and vegetation and soil parameters) is freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Definition.Question: What does the term 'oasis–desert ecosystem interactions' signify in the context of ecological research?
Definition.Answer: Oasis–desert ecosystem interactions refer to the exchange of energy, water vapor, and carbon between oasis and desert systems. Understanding these interactions is crucial for maintaining ecological stability and supporting sustainable development in arid and semi-arid regions.

Definition.Question: How is 'data processing and quality control' defined in the context of collecting ecological datasets?
Definition.Answer: Data processing and quality control involve steps such as data collection, processing, archiving, and sharing. This includes ensuring the accuracy and reliability of data collected from various sources like eddy covariance systems, automatic weather stations, and other auxiliary data on vegetation and soil parameters.

Comparison.Question: How do the challenges of data collection in inland river basins of arid regions compare to those encountered when monitoring phenological changes in mixed forest stations?
Comparison.Answer: Inland river basins face challenges such as ecological degradation, drying water bodies, and land desertification, which can complicate data collection and necessitate long-term observations. Phenological monitoring in mixed forest stations may encounter issues related to data resolution and the need for specific light conditions for accurate image capture. Both settings require careful data processing and quality control, but the environmental challenges and required data adjustments differ.

Interpretation.Question: What insights can be drawn from the use of phenological cameras about seasonal vegetation dynamics and their impact on the oasis-desert ecosystems?
Interpretation.Answer: The use of phenological cameras provides detailed data on vegetation cover and relative greenness index, which can be used to determine key phenological phases such as the start, peak, and end of the growing season. These insights are crucial for understanding the dynamics of vegetation in oasis-desert ecosystems, which play a significant role in maintaining ecological stability and supporting socioeconomic activities in arid and semiarid regions.

Interpretation.Question: How might the integration of eddy covariance systems and automatic weather stations improve the accuracy and reliability of data on energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes in oasis-desert areas?
Interpretation.Answer: The integration of eddy covariance systems, which provide high-resolution data on turbulent fluxes, with automatic weather stations, which collect comprehensive hydrometeorological data, allows for a robust dataset that captures the complex interactions between energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange. This combination enhances the accuracy and reliability of the data, offering a more comprehensive understanding of the oasis-desert ecosystem dynamics and their role in the global carbon cycle.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why are oases significant in the context of arid and semiarid region studies, and how does this impact data collection strategies?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Oases are significant because they support more than 90% of the population in arid regions despite comprising less than 10% of the total area. This unique ecological and socioeconomic role necessitates a focus on maintaining the balance between oasis and desert systems, impacting data collection strategies to ensure sustainable development and ecological security.

Causal Antecedent.Answer: Challenges such as ecological environment degradation, including the drying up of rivers and lakes, natural vegetation degradation, land desertification intensification, and frequent dust storms drive the need for comprehensive observational datasets. These challenges are particularly critical in regions like the Tarim River basin, the Aral Sea basin, and the Lake Urmia basin.

Causal Consequence.Answer: Integrating phenological camera data with traditional hydrometeorological observations may enhance the understanding of vegetation dynamics and their interactions with energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange processes in oasis-desert ecosystems, potentially leading to improved predictions of ecological stability and carbon cycle impacts.

Causal Consequence.Answer: Using eddy covariance systems and scintillometers for long-term data collection may provide detailed insights into energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes in arid and semiarid regions, enabling a better understanding of oasis-desert interactions and contributing to strategies for sustainable development and carbon neutrality goals.

Causal Consequence.Answer: Employing automatic weather stations with short average periods could lead to high-resolution climate data, which may improve the accuracy of hydrometeorological analyses and support comprehensive assessments of ecological environment changes and challenges in inland river basins.

Goal Orientation.Answer: Long-term observations are indispensable to achieve a quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas. This understanding is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases, as well as to support the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality.

Goal Orientation.Question: What motivates the integration of phenological camera observations with data transmission capabilities in mixed forest stations?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The integration of phenological camera observations with data transmission capabilities is motivated by the need to collect time-series data on vegetation dynamics, specifically the relative greenness index (GCC). This data is essential for calculating key phenological parameters, such as the start and end of the growing season, which are crucial for understanding vegetation responses and ecosystem processes.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it critical to achieve a balance between oasis and desert systems in the context of sustainable development?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Achieving a balance between oasis and desert systems is critical to maintain the ecological stability and support the sustainable development of oases. Oases are vital for the ecological environment and economic foundation in arid and semi-arid regions, and their stability is essential for the ecological security and socioeconomic development of these areas, particularly in the context of global climate change.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the steps involved in using phenological cameras to collect and process data for determining key phenophase parameters in mixed forests?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The process involves using a phenological camera positioned vertically downward to collect images with a resolution of 1280x720. The data is collected at specified time intervals. For calculating the greenness index, the relative greenness index (GCC) is determined using the formula GCC=G/(R+G+B), where R, G, and B are the red, green, and blue pixel values of the image. The data then undergoes invalid value filling and smoothing filtration. Finally, key phenophase parameters such as the start, peak, and end of the growing season are determined by fitting to the growth curve.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How is the vegetation cover calculated from images captured by phenological cameras, and what preprocessing steps are necessary?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To calculate vegetation cover, images are preprocessed by selecting those with moderate lighting conditions. The images are segmented into vegetation and soil sections, and the proportion of vegetation pixels within the area of interest is calculated as the cover for each image. After extracting the time series data, the original cover data is smoothed using a filtering process according to a user-specified time window, resulting in the final time series of cover data.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methods are employed to ensure the quality control and processing of hydrometeorological and flux data collected from oasis-desert ecosystems?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Data quality control and processing involve collecting hydrometeorological data (such as radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles) using automatic weather stations with a 10-minute average period. This includes data on gradients of air temperature and humidity, wind speed and direction, air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles. Additionally, turbulent flux data is acquired using an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The data collection process is followed by data processing, archiving, and sharing, ensuring comprehensive quality control.

Enablement.Question: What observational technologies are essential for collecting comprehensive data on energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Enablement.Answer: Observational technologies such as eddy covariance systems, scintillometers, and automatic weather stations are essential for collecting comprehensive data on energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange. These technologies provide half-hourly turbulent flux data and hydrometeorological data, including radiation, soil heat flux, soil temperature profiles, air temperature and humidity gradients, wind speed and direction, air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles.

This combination of methods seems effective in capturing detailed energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes, crucial for understanding oasis–desert interactions and supporting ecological stability and socioeconomic development.

Judgmental.Question: What challenges do you foresee in maintaining and expanding datasets for long-term observations in arid and semiarid regions?
Judgmental.Answer: Challenges in maintaining and expanding datasets in these regions could include environmental degradation such as river and lake drying, vegetation loss, desertification, and dust storms. These factors, coupled with logistical difficulties in harsh climates and remote locations, could pose significant obstacles to consistent data collection and dataset expansion.

Request/Directive.Answer: Challenges in data collection in arid and semiarid inland river basins include ecological degradation like the drying of rivers and lakes, vegetation degradation, land desertification, and dust storms. Overcoming these challenges involves establishing long-term observational networks, such as eddy covariance systems and meteorological stations, to consistently monitor energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes. Implementing quality control procedures and supplementing data with hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters can enhance data reliability and support sustainable development goals in these regions.

Request/Directive.Answer: Data processing and quality control techniques in collecting datasets of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange involve systematic data collection, processing, and archiving. The data collected from eddy covariance systems and meteorological stations undergo quality checks to ensure accuracy. The datasets, which include fluxes, hydrometeorological data, and vegetation and soil parameters, are then archived and shared for broader accessibility, as exemplified by availability through the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center. This rigorous process is essential for understanding oasis–desert interactions and ensuring data usability for ecological and socio-economic research.
